text.p: Ireland's "low-fares no-frills" airline Ryanair Holdings Plc could soar at its take-off on the U.S. stock market due Thursday.

The stock of the Irish airline, which is run by U.S. entrepreneur David Bonderman, will debut on both sides of the Atlantic on the Nasdaq and the Irish stock exchange in an initial public offering of 54,167,596 ordinary shares.

Bonderman, formerly chairman of Continental Airlines Inc, led a $450 million investment that helped bring Continental out of bankruptcy in 1993. He remains the company's largest stockholder and has a seat on its board.
IPO analysts are forecasting, on average, a jump of 1-1/2 points and some are even more optimistic.
"The IPO market is back on. If you can get a two point jump out of Carey, Ryanair should be worth at least three," said Vince Slavin, who tracks IPOs for Cantor Fitzgerald.
Carey International Inc jumped 2-1/2 to 13 after its IPO on Wednesday.
Ryanair, which has been operating since 1985, runs short flights primarily btween Ireland and the United Kingdom.

""Our secret is low fares, low fares and even more low fares. No meals, no frills, no newspapers, no nuts," Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary told reporters earlier this month at an announcement of the flotation.
Ryanair is selling 33.3 million of the total number of shares to be offered while existing stockholders will sell 20.8 million.

In the United States, American Depositary shares will be offered, each representing five shares. The ADSs are estimated to price in a range of 12.28 to 14.52, according to lead underwriter Morgan Stanley and Co.
